content.description: Good to do if you are over this way.  Climb past a couple bolts to Wild and Blue anchors.  The name comes from Amy’s goat, Younghoe, who climbed up the far right side and got stuck on the ledge.
content.location: Right and uphill of Wild and Blue.

content.description: An obscure route on the right side of the face.  The lower section has some really good slabbing.  Starts behind a tree that almost touches the wall.  Follow a few bolts up the slab and trend right to anchors below the massive ledge.

An interesting trad corner with some wavy granite, you will wish it was longer.  Walk up the cake wedge to the obvious corner, place your first piece and start climbing, at the end of the corner stay slightly left and continue straight up the slab to anchors.  A little bit of a runout but it gets easier the higher you go and there is good small gear in the corner before this. A great spot to practice placing gear bring a brush
content.protection: takes excellent gear from #2 to .2, an extra .2 and .3 are nice to have, a .3X4, or red C3 fits nicely at the very top of the climb before the slab section.  Rap rings up top.
content.location: hike up the main pumpkintown trail, when it meets the first section of slab go right, over the ridge bulge, follow the climbers trail and keep an eye up and left, the corner is fairly obvious and is currently the first climb in the table town area.

content.description: A fun and technical traversing slab experience.  Start directly below the bolt with a high foot sloper and move through 5 bolts.  Shares anchors with Smashy Samsquantch, and like its neighbor has a nice runout on easier friction before the end.
content.location: Starts on the left end of the obvious slab on the far left side of the Mini South Face and traverses up and right to the anchors.

climbs.name: Less Chat, More Splat
climbs.fa: Brian Haslam, Candus Wester & Sean Cobourn (ground up) 2020

content.description: Boulder and chimney the mossy start to get established on the face to the left.Then crimp your way up beautiful edges and unlock a few sequences thru the crux at bolt #3. Fun climbing.
content.location: After finding the wall, walk right past a wet steep wall to a large detached flake.  The start is left of the flake.  ASD and Dysrythmia are immediately to the right of this route.  Knacker Cracker is to the right of the huge flake.

climbs.name: Knacker Cracker
climbs.fa: Bryan Haslam, Jeep Gaskin & Candus Wester (ground up) 2020

content.description: Right side of huge detached flake, 75’ right of Dysrhythmia. Classic! Stem inside the chimney to a stance on the face and clip a bolt. From there, chicken wing and thrutch higher with good gear in the corner. Power layback to the top of the corner, catch your breath and delicately slab past 2 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. #4 and #5 Camalots are very helpful. A bold person can do without, but you might cry a little.
content.protection: three bolts, various hand to large cams, anchor up top
content.location: Right side of huge detached flake, 75’ right of Dysrhythmia

climbs.name: Dysrythmia
climbs.fa: Bryan Haslam, Sean Cobourn, Candus Wester, Duncan McWilliam Grench (ground up) 2020

content.description: Locate a pair of cracks formed by a 30’ tall flake. This climbs the right side 4-6” wide crack at left side of huge flake. A #4 camalot is helpful. As the crack ends, climb slab past 3 bolts to a flake to an anchor. Good variety.
content.location: Go right where CCC Trail hits P-Town Wall.  After finding the Mini South Face wall, walk right past a wet steep wall to a large detached flake.  The start of this route is left of the flake.

content.description:
Not really a desirable route, but it does stay dry when the rest of table town is weeping.  There are two cruxes at the bulges with very easy climbing in-between. The lower crux is more challenging.  The upper crux is in the 5.7 range.

 go bolt it if you want but its not worth it.

 you can walk off to climbers left and back down the ridge, or you can continue up the ridge for "easy" top access.
content.location: When the main Climbers trail hits the first section of rock, go straight up the ridge, there are several boulder problems along the way, best one is fireant flavor a nice v0 hand crack, continue up and slightly right, until you can scoot out right onto a ledge this area is technically above the mini south face and may need to be reallocated.

climbs.name: ASD
climbs.fa: Duncan McWilliam Grench, Bryan Haslam, Sean Cobourn, Candus Wester (ground up) 2020

content.description: This is a face climb direct start to Dysrhythmia, that avoids the fat crack then steps to left side of face. Fun, deceptive moves past 2 bolts to join Dysrhythmia above the flake.  This was Duncan's first FA and first time drilling a bolt!
content.protection: bolts, a hidden big cam and some smaller cams for up top if you want.
content.location: Between Less Chat, More Splat and Dysrythmia.  Immediately left of huge flake.

content.description: A shorter, often wet area to the right of where the CCC Trail hits the rock.  It is vaguely reminiscent of Looking Glasses South Face due to the series of natural lines gracing this smaller version.
